#summary Bluetooth SmartCard Readers
#labels SmartCard,RFCOMM

= Introduction =

After RS232 is gone for good, common !SmartCard readers are connected via USB and follow the [http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/DWG_Smart-Card_CCID_Rev110.pdf USB CCID specification].

An open source implementation of the CCID protocol is available as part of the [http://pcsclite.alioth.debian.org/ccid.html PCSC/lite project].

However, there is no Bluetooth specification for !SmartCard readers by the Bluetooth SIG.

In theory, !SmartCard vendors could follow a similar approach as with USB Human Interface Devices (HID), where the 4 USB HID endpoints are mapped to 2 L2CAP channels. Another approach, found with the [http://www.hidglobal.com/prod_detail.php?prod_id=369 HID OMNIKEY 2061 Bluetooth Reader], is to put the TPDUs defined by the CCID specification into a minimal packet and send that over RFCOMM.

= Details for individual readers ==

== [http://www.hidglobal.com/prod_detail.php?prod_id=369 HID OMNIKEY 2061 Bluetooth Reader] ==

After pairing with the default PIN '0000', which could be changed according to the manual, the reader provides an RFCOMM service at channel #1. Over this channel CCID TPDUs can be send. The TPDUs are wrapped in a minimal packet consisting of the start symbol 0xa5 and an XOR checksum over the TPDU.
Responses from the reader are wrapped by the same convention.

Example: the TPDU to turn power on for the first card slot is {{{ 62 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 Â }}. To send it over Bluetooth to the OMNIKEY 2061, you would send {{{ A5 62 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 62 }}} - note the 0x62 at the end, which was easy to calculate in this case :)
